column1: Pargas (Finnish: Parainen) is a town and municipality of Finland
column2: in the Archipelago Sea. The big limestone mine in Pargas is the base of the main industry and except for the central parts
column3: the municipality is still mostly rural.

column1: Pargas is located in Åboland in the province of Western Finland and is part of the Southwest Finland region. It was created as Väståboland on January 1
column6: Houtskär and Iniö were merged into a single municipality.

column1: The municipality has a population of 15
column2: 101 (31 July 2020) and covers an area of 5
column6: 801.73 sq mi) is water. The population density is 17.13 inhabitants per square kilometre (44.4/sq mi).

column1: The town is bilingual with a majority (57.6%) speaking Swedish as their native language.
Pargas has a large limestone industry
column2: with the industry and Nordkalk as an important local employer
column3: agriculture employs many in the rural regions of the municipality. Furthermore
column4: the shipping industry is a relevant industry in the region. The municipality is suffering from high debt.

column1: Archaeological excavations revealed that the vikings used to travel to the archipelago in the 9th century.Karin Thomasdotter (1610–1697)
column2: who served as vogt in Pargas for over forty years
column3: was one of the longest serving vogts
column4: and also one of only two females to have the position in contemporary Finland.

column5: Houtskär and Iniö merged to form the new municipality of Väståboland (Finnish: Länsi-Turunmaa).

column1: Shortly after the merge people started debating if the Väståboland name was the right name for the merged municipality
column2: those arguing against the Väståboland name
column3: proposed Pargas as a 'new' name. The former municipalities could not agree on a new name and Pargas insisted on a change
column4: so the state had to step in and decided the name to be Väståboland. The debates became heated and a referendum was arranged to decide what name the municipality should have in May 2011. The result of the referendum showed that 57
column5: 7% of the voters supported Pargas and 40.1% of voters supported Väståboland. Though the overall majority supported changing the name
column6: there was an overwhelming support for the name Väståboland in 4 out of 5 of the former municipalities. In Iniö only 1 voter out of 173 total voted for Pargas
column7: in all the four 62 out of 2060
column9: 5% voted for Pargas.The municipality council (Swedish: "Fullmäktige") decided on 14 June 2011 in favour of the majority population and decided to rename the municipality Pargas on 1 January 2012. The Council considered to take this issue up again for debate and vote. The council made a re-vote on 6 September 2011 with 25 votes for Pargas

column1: The possibility of merging with Kimitoön to form a single municipality that would include the entire Åboland archipelago has been discussed since 2007
column2: with interest being reignited by the healthcare reforms during the Sipilä Cabinet.
